snippet.title: Netta Bondy @ ReactNext 24` | Animate All the Things! (With View Transitions API)
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Animate All the Things! (With View Transitions API)

Generally speaking, animations kinda suck. They require complicated CSS and JavaScript fine-tuning, often involve state management, and can sometimes break at the slightest touch. They do make for a delightful user experience though, so they‚Äôre worth getting really good at
The View Transitions API provides us with a mechanism to manage animations in single page applications. This native API not only handles transitions, but effectively manages the DOM state change under the hood. And it‚Äôs customizable with some straightforward CSS.
In this talk we‚Äôll look at how to use the View Transitions API using a demo app, and also take a bit of a dive into how this works under the hood.


Netta Bondy
Senior Front End Developer

Netta is a senior front end developer and a lover of all things JavaScript. She has two kids and two cats, one of whom is stopping her from writing this bio any further. Kerrergjlnkhjaf√´

snippet.title: Tal Moskovich @ ReactNext 24` | Enhancing React Performance: Mastering Re-render Optimization
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Enhancing React Performance: Mastering Re-render Optimization

Delve into the realm of React performance optimization with a focus on a simple yet powerful technique to minimize unnecessary re-renders.
This session will explore how maintaining element consistency across renders can significantly improve your application's efficiency. Through practical examples, learn how this approach can lead to drastic reductions in render times, enhancing user experience and application speed.

Tal Moskovich
Frontend & People Developer @ Enpitech

Committing Code & Pushing Personal Boundaries | üßë‚Äçüíª Web Developer | üéß Podcaster & Lecturer |üí°Proactivity Advocate

snippet.title: Sagi Liba @ ReactNext 24` | Events As A Communication Pattern
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)

Events As A Communication Pattern

Working with any framework eventually develops a mindset for its best practices, and React is no different.
After years of experience working with React, I've become accustomed to thinking that the communication methods we've always been using (context, parent-child, child-parent) are the only ways to communicate with React components.
When you start looking at your application with a framework agnostic mindset, questions starts popping up, "Can I send custom events in React?", "What's the right way of doing it?", "Is it an anti-pattern to work with events in React?", etc...
This lecture will cover exactly these questions, and how to use Custom Events with React, and which pitfalls to avoid.

Sagi Liba
Frontend Architect

I help React developers stand out from the crowd, differentiate themselves, and become senior developers faster, by Architecting React Infrastructures.
I‚Äôm a Frontend Architect, and have worked on many advanced projects for some of the most successful cyber security companies in the world (CyberArk & Pentera).
My obsession for building frontend infrastructures and the years I‚Äôve dedicated to it, had led me to uncover the rules and best-practices that exist in any React infrastructure, which I‚Äôm sharing with you today.

snippet.title: Omri Lavi @ ReactNext 24` | The Superpower of ASTs: How We Saved 16% on Our Bundle Size
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


The Superpower of ASTs: How We Saved 16% on Our Bundle Size

In this session I will explain about the development of a special Babel loader, that allowed us to decrease our bundle size by a whopping 16%. We did this by inlining constant objects directly into the referencing code, reducing the need for including huge files at the bundle output. We actually achieved better improvement than Webpack‚Äôs tree-shaking! This was allowed by harnessing the power of Babel‚Äôs AST tools: utilizing their potentials may yield dramatic results, unattainable by other manners.
In this sessions I will explain about:
* What are ASTs and why are they useful
* How to develop AST-based tools
* Some limitations of tree-shaking
* Strategies for writing custom bundler plugins
* A secret tip for avoiding our mistake
Join us for a new outlook on ASTs with insights that might surprise you!


Omri Lavi
DevTools Tech Lead @ Monday

With over a decade of industry experience, I've been an engineer at monday.com for the past 2+ years as part of the DevTools group. In this role, our overarching mission centers on creating powerful, user-friendly, and well-documented tools designed to empower developers, ultimately fostering efficiency and job satisfaction within the team. My responsibilities extend beyond coding; I actively engage in understanding the nuanced needs of our developers, ensuring that the tools we build resonate with their workflows and aspirations.

snippet.title: Ran Bar-Zik @ ReactNext 24` | Do not let your React be injected
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)

Do not let your React be injected

Security issues are not only on the server side! With simple methods, malicious attackers can hijack your beautifully crafted React application and turn it into a disaster area.
In this session, we will learn about injection attacks and, more importantly, several techniques that help us protect against malicious injections. From SRI to CSP with the particular culprits in React. With real-life examples on Next.js (SSR) and Vite.js.

Ran Bar-Zik
Senior software architect @ CyberArk

15+ years of development experience, Blogger at internet-israel.com, author of "Learn Javascript in Hebrew", "Learn Node.js in Hebrew", "Learn React in Hebrew" and "Learn MySQL in Hebrew".

snippet.title: Ofir Elarat @ ReactNext 24` | Core Web Vitals ‚Äì Measuring Performance Like a Pro
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Core Web Vitals ‚Äì Measuring Performance Like a Pro

In today's digital world, a fast and smooth website isn't just nice to have; it's essential for keeping your audience engaged and driving success. But how do you measure what "fast and smooth" actually means? Just recently, the answer became simple: ‚ÄúCore Web Vitals‚Äù
In this talk, we‚Äôll show you exactly how these metrics are reshaping the way we think about web performance. We'll explore how they influence not just user experience but also your site's visibility on Google. More importantly, you'll learn practical tips and strategies to improve your site based on these vital metrics and start measuring performance like a pro.


Ofir Elarat
Software Engineer @ Mixtiles

My love affair with coding ignited in high school,
where I delved into the creation of apps, websites, and various small projects for both fun and continuous learning.
With each line of code, I find joy in unraveling the complexities of this ever-evolving field.
From Cloud to Mobile to Web Development I always find aspects that excite me and I‚Äôm always eager to learn more.
I served as a Full Stack Developer in the IDF, working on various large scale projects but also creating the unit‚Äôs tech podcast.
In addition to my hands-on projects,
I maintain a medium profile where I share insights and articles on diverse topics within computer science.
Currently I work as a Software Engineer at Mixtiles.

snippet.title: Noam Honig @ ReactNext 24` | Simplifying React Dialogs with Awaitable Promises
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Simplifying React Dialogs with Awaitable Promises

In modern web development, managing user interactions through modals and dialogs is a common yet often cumbersome task.
Traditional methods in React involve maintaining "open" states and handling outcomes through "onClick" events.
This approach, especially when dealing with complex user flows or multiple confirm steps, quickly becomes unwieldy, reminiscent of the callback patterns of old server-side interactions.
With the evolution of asynchronous programming, the use of callbacks has been largely supplanted by the more elegant and readable async/await pattern for server calls.
Why not apply the same evolution to how we handle user interactions in React?
In this talk, we propose a transformative approach: utilizing dialogs as awaitable promises. This method allows developers to write intuitive and linear business logic, akin to using if (await dialog("question")) {...} for handling user inputs, streamlining the process of complex user flows and decision trees within applications.


Noam Honig
Creator of Remult

Coder, open-sourcerer, developer experience enthusiast, software architect, and entrepreneur. At work, I oversee and consult in enterprise legacy systems modernization for fortune 500s to small businesses. Outside work I love helping NGOs as a full-stack developer and mentor.

snippet.title: Noam Tahor Shafran and Tom Carpel @ ReactNext 24` | Lazy Brilliance
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)

Lazy Brilliance: Unveiling the Power of Codebase Preservation in React

Imagine a world where embracing laziness becomes a strategic advantage in React application development. In this presentation, we challenge the conventional practice of purging old code. We will explore how our team's seemingly counterintuitive decision to stop deleting old codepaths has not only streamlined our React development process but has also acted as an unforeseen safety net in times of crisis. In other words, our laziness became a wellspring of real-time resilience.
Join this session to explore how an embrace of relics in the code can enhance resilience, expedite recovery, and provide unexpected solutions to the challenges faced by front-end developers using the React framework. Gain insights into how this unorthodox strategy not only provides unexpected solutions, but also transforms old code flows from a perceived liability into an invaluable asset.

Noam Tahor Shafran
Engineering Manager @ Remitly 

Noam began her journey with Remitly 4.5 years ago as a junior front-end developer and quickly evolved professionally. Today, she leads a team of full-stack developers in charge of the Rewire by Remitly financial platform. With a BSc in Computer Science from Tel Aviv-Yafo Academic College, prior to joining Rewire (now Remitly Israel), Noam gained professional experience from leading tech companies such as Check Point.
Outside of work, Noam raises her three year old daughter together with her partner and her goal is to effectively manage these two worlds in a way that leads to further growth and development.

Tom Carpel
Director of Engineering @ Remitly 

Tom has over 15 years of software development and engineering management experience. With a BSc in Computer Science and Engineering from UCLA under his belt, Tom‚Äôs career includes working at some of the biggest companies in the San Francisco Bay Area such as Box and Cisco. Upon his return to Israel, Tom started working at the fintech startup Rewire (now Remitly Israel). When not working, Tom likes to walk (his dog) and run (for fun and occasionally in a marathon).

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)

Evolving JavaScript: Cultivating Genetic Algorithms for Creative Coding

When was the moment you first realized that coding was pure joy? We all need a well-deserved break from feature releases, meetings, bug fixes, tech debt, and 10X burnout! Join me in exploring delightful, interactive experiences, inspired by nature, that we as JavaScript developers can create with our everyday coding skills. We‚Äôll learn about genetic algorithms, what they‚Äôre good for, and how to code with them, including a demo. Adding state machines and generative art into the mix, our small step into the world of AI programming will enable us to produce problem solving agents that are as intelligent as they are beautiful!


Kevin Maes
Software Engineer @ Stately.ai

Kevin moved his first pixels back in the days of Flash animation, working at startups in Tel Aviv and NYC. He‚Äôs done development, consulting, and engineering management at companies like NBC Universal, Thomson Reuters, and Giant Machines. He is currently building Stately Studio as an engineer at Stately.ai. When not at a computer, Kevin enjoys opera, spending time with his family, and traveling.

snippet.title: Matan Borenkraout @ ReactNext 24` | Playwright Component Tests: Are they the Testing-Library killer?
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Playwright Component Tests: Are they the Testing-Library killer?

As the React ecosystem evolves, so do our testing strategies. In this session, we delve into the fascinating world of component testing, pitting two heavyweight contenders against each other: Playwright Component Tests and the long time champion Testing Library. I, as one of Testing-Library's maintainers will try to honestly answer "which one reigns supreme?" Buckle up as we understand what are the two options, explore their strengths and weaknesses through examples, realize what are the API differences, what are the performance aspects and understand whether Playwright Component Tests have what it takes to dethrone the Testing Library.


Matan Borenkraout
Senior Software Engineer @ Microsoft

Matan is a Senior Software Engineer at Microsoft, speaker and a tech blog writer. He is a React enthusiast and a Testing Library maintainer who's aiming to understand how things work rather than satisfying on a given API. Matan believes that knowledge is worth nothing if not shared.

snippet.title: Guy Nesher @ ReactNext 24` | JavaScript Minigames
snippet.description:

Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


JavaScript Minigames

Mini-games are small, easily developed games that rely on a single mechanic that can be played in under five minutes‚Äîlike Flappy Bird, 2048, or the more recent 1D Pac-Man.
Developing them is a great way to hone your JavaScript skills, express your imagination, and, hopefully, have some fun.
In this talk, we will see how we can expand on our existing skillset to start developing games.


Guy Nesher
Team lead @ Redis

Lawyer turned web developer back in Israel after spending 6 years in London. When he isn't building stuff, you can generally find him traveling the world

snippet.title: Gal Weizman @ ReactNext 24` |
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


What can traditional web application security learn from browser wallet extensions?

Is securing a crypto browser wallet the same as securing a traditional web app?
In this talk we will focus on the unique challenges of securing browser wallets.
While browser wallets are normal JavaScript Web extensions for the most part, their unique architecture requires a
somewhat special security approach as their threat model is eventually different from traditional web applications.
This means that while traditional security threats such as XSS, Phishing, Supply Chain Attacks, etc still apply to
browser wallets, the way to address them can be different and more challenging given their unique architecture.
This sets browser wallets to be a great use case to learn about clientside security from by making us ask ourselves:
What can we learn from the security challenges browser wallets have to deal with that cab be applied to traditional web application?



Gal Weizman
JavaScript Security Engineer @ MetaMask

Gal is an expert in browser JavaScript and client side security with close to a decade of proven experience in multiple fields, ranging from vulnerability research and bots mitigation, through application and supply chain security to anti debugging research, browser extensions security and more. Gal is also an experienced speaker with multiple performances in well known conferences and podcasts and is responsible for some popular findings and discoveries in the browser security space.

snippet.title: Evyatar Alush @ ReactNext 24` | Re-Form the future. Rethinking Form Validations in React
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Re-Form the future. Rethinking Form Validations in React

Forms are at the backbone of the web, but building and validating them can be a tangled mess of code and frustration. As they get more complex, they become harder to write, maintain, and validate effectively.
Introducing a new way of validating forms in React, using Vest - a library that changes the way we handle form validation using the expressive syntax and style of testing libraries.
We will cover the history of forms on the web, why they are so hard to validate - and how to fix them. We'll step up our form validation game by taking a complex form, and together write its validations using Vest.


Evyatar Alush
Front End Engineer @ Meta

Evyatar Alush is a Front End Engineer at Meta who is passionate about open source development. He works on multiple open source projects, including the Vest Validations Framework, and volunteers as a mentor to support new engineers entering the open source community. Evyatar cares deeply about API design and improving the developer experience.

A Deep Dive into Fine-Grained Reactivity and the future of Signals

In the dynamic world of web development, crafting responsive and efficient user interfaces is paramount. As web developers, we often find ourselves navigating the challenges of managing complex state changes and ensuring that our applications respond seamlessly to user interactions. This talk aims to explore the realm of fine-grained reactivity and signals within web development, shedding light on advanced techniques to elevate your application's performance and maintainability.

I'm a Google Developer Expert (GDE) for Angular.
Experienced FE developer, specialized in high performance applications.
Founder & CEO @ e-square.io.

snippet.title: Asaf Shochet Avida @ ReactNext 24` | Mastering React Component Library Optimization
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Shaking Things Up: Mastering React Component Library Optimization

Managing a growing component library can be quite a puzzle. The more it expands, the heavier it gets with larger bundle sizes, dependencies multiplying, and the overall complexity going through the roof. And let's face it, it's a headache when every project using the library ends up dragging the entire package, even when they just need a single component ü§¶.
But worry not! That's where tree-shaking steps in to save the day!
In this talk, I will spill the beans on my experience fine-tuning a React component library that boasts over 40 components and serves various projects. We'll roll up our sleeves and dig into the world of tree shaking, talk about what you need to get it up and running smoothly and untangle some tricky terms like commonJS vs. ES modules, peer dependencies, and the whole multi-bundle exports thing.
Get ready for some down-to-earth, practical insights that can save you a refactor or two.


Asaf Shochet Avida
Frontend Tech Lead @ Evinced

Asaf is the front-end tech lead @Evinced, with 13+ years of experience under his belt, including frontend, backend, and test automation (go testing!), and a special place in his heart for shiny CI pipelines.
He loves reading Harry Potter with his daughter, mentoring junior devs, and making bonfires with his family.

snippet.title: Ariel Shulman @ ReactNext 24` | Conquering Concurrent React
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)

Conquering Concurrent React

The most important addition in React 18 is something we hope you never have to think about: concurrency‚Äù- React@18 documentation
Well, in this talk - we ARE going to think about it!
React‚Äôs new mental model is not easy to wrap our heads around, and that‚Äôs where this talk comes in. We will learn how concurrency works in React bottom up, what problems it solves, and how SSR and streaming components fit in the picture.
By the end of this talk we will understand the newest technologies around us, whether it‚Äôs React‚Äôs concurrent features such as Suspense and React Lazy or the new Next.js App router

Ariel Shulman
Full Stack Developer @ Illumex

Ariel is a Full Stack developer with a passion for designing scalable applications, understanding how things work under the hood, and public speaking about all the above.
When she's not behind a keyboard she's probably surfing or playing guitar.

snippet.title: Yoav Abrahami @ ReactNext 24` | Where the future is heading for JS Frameworks‚Ä¶
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference
www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Where the future is heading for JS Frameworks‚Ä¶

React, Angular, Vue, Svelte are the leading frameworks today, and rightly so. But all of them as well as other ‚Äúcurrent generation‚Äù frameworks have limitations.. In order to better prepare for what‚Äôs coming next as developers, let‚Äôs talk about the next challenges facing JS frameworks, learning from history and outlining how our future will look like.

Having spent the past few years building a next generation framework myself, I have lots of insights and a good perspective to share, as I‚Äôve done a fair bit of research on the topic.
We‚Äôll talk about Signals, Web Components, Qwik and a whole new way of thinking about traditional frameworks. So strap on the seatbelts‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre getting in the delorean‚Ä¶ back to the future!


Yoav Abrahami
Chief Architect & Head of coding products @Wix engineering.

Working at Wix for 14 years, a father of two kids, mountain biker & 30 years in tech. Always looking to innovate and do interesting things.

snippet.title: Adi Achituve @ ReactNext 24` | Responsive Design vs. Adaptive Design
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Responsive Design vs. Adaptive Design: Advanced Techniques in React Apps

In this session, we will explore "adaptive" and "responsive" design within the context of the latest React development. We'll break down these concepts with everyday examples, discovering what screen breakpoints are and how they come into play.
Introducing container queries, the latest CSS feature that replaces traditional media queries, offering a more efficient approach to achieving adaptive layouts.
Just clear insights and straightforward examples make it easy to understand. By the end, you'll gain practical skills to ensure your React apps run perfectly on any screen.


Adi Achituve
Senior Front-End Web Developer @ Lightricks

Adi is an experienced Front-End Web developer with over 8 years of expertise, focusing on making React applications work smoothly. She is known for her precise attention to detail, especially in CSS and styling, ensuring apps are pixel-perfect across various browsers and screens. She loves working on complex projects, architecture, and researching new technologies while investigating how browsers work.
Apart from coding, Adi has a strong passion for UX design, believing in making applications not only high-performing but also user-friendly, ensuring they meet the highest standards of both design and functionality.

snippet.title: Gil Fink @ ReactNext 24` | Losing your Components‚Äô Head
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Losing your Components‚Äô Head

Every web project will eventually need a components library and no matter which framework you are using. But, the requirements in each project are different and even if you will find a component library, it will have it's own opinionated UI look and feel or rendering. This is where headless components can help you achieve your project's goals. Join me to understand what are headless components and why you should consider using this pattern in your projects.


Gil Fink
CEO and Senior Consultant @ sparXys

Gil Fink is a web development expert, Web Technologies GDE and sparXys CEO. He is currently consulting for various enterprises and companies, where he helps to develop web based solutions. He is also co-author of several Microsoft Official Courses (MOCs) and training kits and co-author of "Pro Single Page Application Development" book (Apress).

snippet.title: Gil Tayar @ ReactNext 24` | Towards a simpler JavaScript ecosystem
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


Towards a simpler JavaScript ecosystem

The history of the JavaScript ecosystem can be described as a move from a simple ecosystem with no tooling (just write the code and F5!) in the 90s, towards the current wave of massive tooling which nobody understands but which helps us mitigate the deficiencies in browsers and the internet.
Are we stuck there? I believe we aren‚Äôt.
I aim to bring a vision that returns full circle to an ecosystem with little to no tooling. It shows that with modern technologies like import maps, web bundles, the type annotations proposal, 103 Early Hints, and others, we can bring back the simplicity of the early ecosystem, while not sacrificing the advantages of the current one.
This talk presents this vision, and describes the technologies and techniques that enable this return to simplicity.


Gil Tayar
Senior Architect @ Microsoft

35 years of experience have not dulled the fascination Gil Tayar has with software development. His passion is distributed systems and figuring out how to scale development to big teams. Extreme modularity and testing are the main tools in his toolbelt, using them to combat the code spaghetti monster as a software architect at companies like Wix, Applitools, and at his current job as software engineer at Microsoft.
In his private life, he is a dad to two lovely kids, an avid reader of Science Fiction, and a passionate film buff. Unfortunately for him, he hasn‚Äôt answered the big question of his life‚Äîwhat‚Äôs better, static or dynamic languages? But he‚Äôs working on it.

snippet.title: Evyatar Daud @ ReactNext 24` | React Query Under the Hood
snippet.description:
ReactNext 2024
Israel's largest Frontend Conference

www.react-next.com
Brought to you by EventHandler (www.eventhandler.co.il)


React Query Under the Hood

Have you ever wondered how React Query works under the hood? What magic does it use to be so fast and responsive? How to write your own implementation and get better at writing such libraries? You‚Äôve come to the right place!
In this talk, we are going to dive into how React Query works, how it handles caching, how it manages multiple requests at the same time without wasting network resources, and how it works cross-framework without needing to rewrite its core components.
This talk is intended for experienced developers and assumes that you‚Äôve used React Query in the past, and are familiar with concepts such as custom hooks, pub-sub mechanism, React data-syncing patterns, and a little bit about caching and promises.


Evyatar Daud
Senior Full Stack Developer @ Elementor

Evyatar Daud is a Senior Full-Stack Developer at Elementor. Discovering his passion for software development at the age of 12, he began teaching himself how to code, mainly focusing on frontend development. Today, he is an open-source contributor, a mentor, and a public speaker. In his free time, he explores TypeScript libraries' code and creates art using a single div and a lot of CSS.
